Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, boots still caked with dust from the site, when I noticed my grandson slumped over his homework, eyes clouded with worry. My heart ached to reach out, to offer the kind of gentle words my own grandmother once gave me—reminders that storms pass, that he’s stronger than he thinks. But just as I opened my mouth, my phone buzzed. It was a message from the foreman: a spill had been spotted in the walkway, and I was the closest to the site. Safety was on my shoulders; if someone slipped, it would be on me. I looked at my grandson, so small and lost, and then at my phone, the weight of responsibility pressing in from both sides. My mind raced—do I stay and be the grandmother he needs, or do I rush back to the site and be the laborer my crew depends on? The clock ticked, and I felt torn in two, each role pulling me in a different direction, both demanding more than I had to give.
